stem: The intensive care nurse is analyzing ABG results for three clients with multiple comorbidities. Based on the documentation in the Complex Laboratory Flowsheet, match each lab profile to its correct pathological driver.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
Patient A: 65y/o male with COPD (Chronic CO2 retainer) currently in AKI. 
Patient B: 28y/o female with DKA (Metabolic Acidosis) who was just given a high-dose sedative (Respiratory depression). 
Patient C: 50y/o male with chronic vomiting (Metabolic Alkalosis) following a panic attack (Hyperventilation).

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content:
Patient B: BP 88/54, HR 132, RR 10 (Shallow). 
Patient C: BP 110/68, HR 118, RR 42 (Rapid).

rows.text: pH 7.18, High CO2, Low HCO3 (Double Acidosis)
pH 7.58, Low CO2, High HCO3 (Double Alkalosis)
pH 7.28, High CO2, Low HCO3 (Mixed Resp/Met Acidosis)

rationale.correct: Mixed Respiratory & Metabolic Acidosis (c1) occurs when the lungs can't breathe (High CO2) AND the kidneys/body cells are failing (Low HCO3), as seen in r1 and r3. The pH drops dangerously low because NO compensation is possible. Mixed Respiratory & Metabolic Alkalosis (c2) occurs when the lungs are hyperventilating (Low CO2) AND the body is losing acid (High HCO3), as seen in r2.
clinicalPearls: Mixed imbalances are the most dangerous because the body has no system left to compensate.
In Mixed Acidosis, the pH will be significantly lower than in a simple imbalance.
Check the 'Drivers': If BOTH CO2 and HCO3 are moving in the 'wrong' direction for the pH, it's a mixed state.

questionTrap.trap: Trying to find a 'primary' driver in a mixed case.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: In mixed cases, BOTH systems are drivers. CO2 is high (Acidosis) and HCO3 is low (Acidosis). They are working together to ruin the pH.

mnemonic.title: Double Trouble
mnemonic.expansion: If CO2 and HCO3 both yell 'Acid', the result is a Disaster (Mixed Acidosis).
